snippet: A five-member panel ruled that the State Senate did not violate the Open Meetings Law before voting to legalize same-sex unions.
abstract: New York State Supreme Court Appellate Division rules that State Senate did not violate Open Meetings Law in 2011 when it considered whether to legalize same-sex marriage; court refuses to nullify the marriages performed under the law; ruling is in response to a lawsuit from conservative group New Yorkers for Constitutional Freedoms, which lobbied against the same-sex marriage bill, and challenged it in courts after it passed.
lead_paragraph: A five-member panel ruled that the State Senate did not violate the Open Meetings Law before voting to legalize same-sex unions.

headline.seo: Same-Sex Marriage Law Allowed to Stand in New York Court Ruling
headline.main: Court Rejects Argument Against Gay Marriage Bill
headline.print_headline: Court Rejects Argument Against Gay Marriage Bill

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject
